definition: hidden inner properties and their external manifestations (TCM)
Tibet/Xizang 西藏
storehouse/depository/Buddhist or Taoist scripture
to conceal/to hide away/to harbor/to store/to collect
elephant/CL:隻|只[zhi1]/shape/form/appearance/to imitate

sentences.english: The theory of Mingmen (Life-Gate) has further enriched the doctrine of Viscera and Their Manifestations in traditional Chinese Medicine.
sentences.chinese: 命門學說爲中醫學的藏象學說增加了新的內容。

sentences.english: The theory of five elements is a main clue of the doctrine of viscera-state of CM (chinese Medicine).
sentences.chinese: 五行學說是中醫藏象理論的主要基礎之一。

sentences.english: "Liver is the root of Baji (endurance)" is an important content of Zangxiang doctrine.
sentences.chinese: “肝者，罷極之本”是藏象學說的重要內容之一。

sentences.english: Viscera-state doctrine, as a basis of TCM theory, has come into being for more than two thousand years.
sentences.chinese: 藏象學說作爲中醫理論的基石已形成兩千多年。

definition: The Yellow Emperor's Internal Canon, medical text c. 300 BC
pattern-syndrome identification based on the eight principles (TCM)
energy channels/meridian (TCM)/(dialect) trick/tactic
the Divine Pivot or Spiritual Pivot, ancient Chinese medical text
(TCM) the three truncal cavities (thoracic, abdominal and pelvic), known as the "triple heater" or "San Jiao"
inner organs
five viscera of TCM, namely: heart 心[xin1], liver 肝[gan1], spleen 脾[pi2], lungs 肺[fei4] and kidneys 腎|肾[shen4]
twelve channels of TCM
"eight principles," a method of giving a general description and syndrome differentiation (TCM)
yin and yang

(TCM) six bowels (hollow organs), namely: gall bladder 膽|胆[dan3], stomach 胃[wei4], large intestine 大腸|大肠[da4 chang2], small intestine 小腸|小肠[xiao3 chang2], triple heater 三焦[san1 jiao1], bladder 膀胱[pang2 guang1]

acupuncture point (any point on any meridian)/category of 12 specific acupuncture points near the wrist or ankle, each lying on a different meridian (one of five categories collectively termed 五輸穴|五输穴)
abbr. for 黃帝內經|黄帝内经[Huang2 di4 Nei4 jing1], The Yellow Emperor's Internal Canon, medical text c. 300 BC
interpretation of the cause/onset and process of an illness/pathogenesis
traditional Chinese medicine/TCM
traditional Chinese medical science/a doctor trained in Chinese medicine
